page.title: 08WOOL INDUSTRY
page.content: Many local people used to be employed in the woollen industry. Over the last 20 year there has been a rapid decline. Two mills are still in use one being Dobroyd reopened by John Woodhead Ltd. about 10 years ago. Wool is bought from Australia and New Zealand, Nylon comes from ICI. After being dyed at local dyeworks the wool is weighed by colours and the fibres mixed and spun in numerous processes many of the machines being computer controlled. After being tested it is exported all over the world as yarn for loom weaving or knitting machines; much is used for making clothes for Marks and Spencers (chain store). 100 people are employed including 7 who started on a youth training scheme. Dobroyd Mill covers a vast area and some of it is sub-let to a garage, a food firm and a wallpaper maker.
